00040 #ifndef actorcontainerbase_h
00041 #define actorcontainerbase_h
00042 
00043 //Internal includes
00044 #include "actorbase.h"
00045 #include "world.h"
00046 
00047 namespace phys
00048 {
00049 
00050 
00051     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00052     /// @class ActorContainerBase
00053     /// @headerfile actorcontainerbase.h
00054     /// @brief A base class to unify the interface for different kinds of containers for holding actors
00055     /// @details Containers for actors must implement atleast this interface(abstract base class) to
00056     /// be usable with the phys::World for tracking in game objects. There are several reasons why this
00057     /// will be useful. Our first thought was deriving from this and an STL container like vector or
00058     /// list. Members of this class should be implementing or inheriting a proper container\n\n
00059     /// The phys world will use one of these containers to store all of the actors for tracking purposes
00060     /// Since  \n\n
00061     /// Currently, you cannot simply swap one member of this with another, in a running phys::World. We are
00062     /// Looking into the feasibility of implementing this. \n\n
00063     /// However the is no reason an actor could be in multiple containers so this could be a viable work
00064     /// around for actor sorting and categorization at runtime. \n\n
00065     /// Because of this classes representation of a cursor only 1 thread at a time should use the cursor
00066     /// movement functions. For the container that the phys::World keeps it should be assume that the
00067     /// cursor is used. For other containers you should manage you container carefully and/or use another
00068     /// iteration method, such as STL iterators.
00069     class ActorContainerBase
00070     {
00071         private:
00072             /// @brief This is expected to be a pointer to the world this will be rendered with and built on
00073             World* ParentWorld;
00074 
00075         public:
00076             /// @brief Basic Constructor
00077             /// @details This just assigned the passed pointer to ParentWorld
00078             /// @param ParentWorld_ This is the world that will perform physics and graphical work on the actors in this container
00079             ActorContainerBase(World* ParentWorld_);
00080 
00081             /// @brief This will add an Actor to this container and the world
00082             /// @details This will add an Actor to this container and the world, and handle the nitty gritty details
00083             /// of add this to physics subsystem and graphics subsystem. \n\n
00084             /// This will not add the Actor to any specific location in the ordering of the container.
00085             /// @param ActorToAdd This is a pointer to the actor to add
00086             virtual void AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd) = 0;
00087 
00088             /// @brief This provides an easy way to access the last Actor added to this container
00089             /// @details For many containers this will simply return a pointer to the last actorl
00090             virtual ActorBase* LastActorAdded() = 0;
00091 
00092             /// @brief Remove an Actor
00093             /// @details Remove all references of the actor pointed from the container. Will throw an exception when attempting to remove
00094             /// and no match could be found.
00095             virtual void RemoveActor(ActorBase* ActorToRemove) = 0;
00096 
00097             /// @brief Removes the current actor
00098             /// @details This removes the actor the cursor at. Will throw an exception when attempting to remove from an empty container.
00099             /// Where the cursor goes is implementation dependent.
00100             virtual void RemoveActorAtCursor() = 0;
00101 
00102             /// @brief Returns how many actors this stores
00103             /// @return This returns a Whole number with the count of actors
00104             virtual Whole GetActorCount() const = 0;
00105 
00106             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the first item in the container
00107             /// @details This moves the cursor to the first item in the container change or return anything else.
00108             /// An exception will be throw if there are no valid items to move to with the cursor. There must be atleast one item to use any cursor
00109             /// moving functions.
00110             virtual void CursorToFirst() = 0;
00111 
00112             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the previous item in the container
00113             /// @details This moves the cursor to the previous item in the container, and if you started at the last item, you will
00114             /// visit every item in a properly implemented container, except for items that may have bee added during your traversal.
00115             /// It is also posible this could visit the same actor twice or more. When called from the first item this does nothing.
00116             /// An exception will be throw if there are no valid items to move to with the cursor. There must be atleast one item to use any cursor
00117             /// moving functions.
00118             virtual void CursorToPrevious() = 0;
00119 
00120             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the next item in the container
00121             /// @details This is the same as CursorToPrevious() except if you start from the begin you'll work your way to the end. If
00122             /// you are at the end, you'll stay their if you call this again
00123             virtual void CursorToNext() = 0;
00124 
00125             /// @brief This moves the cursor to the last item in the container
00126             /// @details This moves the cursor to the last item in the container change or return anything else. See CursorToFirst() for more details.
00127             virtual void CursorToLast() = 0;
00128 
00129             /// @brief This gets the actor at the cursor
00130             /// @details This gets the actor at the cursor, and will not move the cursor. If the cursor has not be set to a location, any valid
00131             /// actor in the container could be returned. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00132             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase.
00133             virtual ActorBase* GetAtCursor() const = 0;
00134 
00135             /// @brief This gets the first actor in the container
00136             /// @details This and the actor the cursor points at after CursorToFirst() should match.
00137             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00138             virtual ActorBase* GetFirst() const = 0;
00139 
00140             /// @brief This gets the last actor in the container
00141             /// @details This and the actor the cursor points at after CursorToLast() should match.
00142             /// @return This returns a pointer to an ActorBase. Will throw an exception when attempting to get from an empty container.
00143             virtual ActorBase* GetLast() const = 0;
00144 
00145 
00146 
00147             /// @brief Which kind of container it this anyway.
00148             /// @details Since this interface could be used with any type of containers and innumerable 3rd party container implemention this
00149             /// can be used to more safely cast this container to a more specific type.
00150             /// @return This returns a phys::String
00151             virtual String GetType() const = 0;
00152 
00153     };
00154 }
00155 
00156 #endif
Generated on Tue Jun 8 09:44:06 2010 for PhysGameEngine by  1.6.3
